docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican party plans today to introduce a Seniors' Health Care Bill of Rights, according to an op-ed piece in The Washington Post by Michael S. Steele, the chairman of the Republican National Committee.

headline.main: Updated: Various Takes on the GOP and Health Care

docs.abstract: The op-ed articles from three newspapers offer a variety of views of Republicans and health care.
docs.snippet: The op-ed articles from three newspapers offer a variety of views of Republicans and health care.

headline.main: Buying Into the Health of the Planet

docs.abstract: An economist draws parallels between the climate-change debate and the health-care debate in Washington, and discusses a cap-and-dividend proposal.
docs.snippet: An economist draws parallels between the climate-change debate and the health-care debate in Washington, and discusses a cap-and-dividend proposal.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reaganomics has failed to deliver what it promised, yet people still believe that government intervention is bad, and leaving the private sector to its own devices is good.
docs.snippet: Reaganomics has failed to deliver what it promised, yet people still believe that government intervention is bad, and leaving the private sector to its own devices is good.

docs.lead_paragraph: In reality, the health care wrestling match is less a test of President Obama’s political genius than it is a test of the Democratic Party’s ability to govern and deliver on its most significant promises.
docs.snippet: In reality, the health care wrestling match is less a test of President Obama’s political genius than it is a test of the Democratic Party’s ability to govern and deliver on its most significant promises.

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats said they were increasingly confident that they could pass a bill that includes a public plan with a simple majority in the Senate.

headline.main: Senate Democrats Consider Tactic to Push Through Government Health Plan
headline.print_headline: Senate Democrats Consider Tactic to Push Through Government Health Plan

docs.snippet: Democrats said they were increasingly confident that they could pass a bill that includes a public plan with a simple majority in the Senate.

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Barney Frank could have been more civil in a town hall last week, but his response was a refreshing change from the pandering coming from other members of Congress.
docs.snippet: Representative Barney Frank could have been more civil in a town hall last week, but his response was a refreshing change from the pandering coming from other members of Congress.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman urged the Obama administration to consider postponing an overhaul of the health care system until the economy improves.

headline.main: Lieberman Suggests Health Care Reform May Have to Wait
headline.print_headline: McCain Says Public Option Must Be Dropped for Compromise

byline.original: By JOSEPH BERGER and DERRICK HENRY

docs.lead_paragraph: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below:
docs.abstract: Your Jokes | Celine Dion is pregnant again. Her morning sickness is an odd occurrence. Normally, she makes other people throw up. -- Alan Ray, Stockton, Calif.
docs.snippet: Your Jokes | Celine Dion is pregnant again. Her morning sickness is an odd occurrence. Normally, she makes other people throw up. -- Alan Ray, Stockton, Calif.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lieberman Weighs In | 6 p.m. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the independent from Connecticut whose vote is vital to the Democrats, is advising that President Obama wait on the health-care overhaul. Here is a portion of the transcript from "CNN's State of the Union," and Senator Lieberman's exchange with the host, John King:

headline.main: Lieberman Wants a Timeout on the Overhaul

docs.abstract: On the talk shows, Joseph I. Lieberman says that the health care overhaul should wait until the recession is over. John McCain says he misses the skills of the ailing Edward Kennedy and adds that President Obama must drop the public option.
docs.snippet: On the talk shows, Joseph I. Lieberman says that the health care overhaul should wait until the recession is over. John McCain says he misses the skills of the ailing Edward Kennedy and adds that President Obama must drop the public option.

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the stronger arguments for changing the health care system lies in the fact that it has left tens of millions of citizens uninsured, creating a medical underclass whose members receive care - if they receive care - mostly in expensive hospital emergency rooms. Critics of the public insurance option claim the number is inflated, as it may include large numbers of people who qualify for Medicaid but haven't applied, who are only temporarily uninsured or who are noncitizens. (Indeed, many commenters here oppose the public option because they don't want to pay for health care delivered to illegal immigrants.)
docs.abstract: An editorial in The Times today tallies the uninsured.
docs.snippet: An editorial in The Times today tallies the uninsured.
